DOC.brief_summary: This research study will evaluate a standalone software application and is designed to standardize and validate new neurocognitive screening testing for children aged 6 through 11, and adolescents and adults ages 12 through 75. The purpose of this study is to evaluate recently developed computerized tasks sensitive to changes in neurocognitive performance after a concussion. These tests were designed to help measure the effects of concussion on cognitive processes (e.g., memory, attention, brain speed) and visual functioning.
DOC.brief_title: Development of a Neurocognitive Screening Test
DOC.criteria: Age: 1275 (Adult version), 611 (pediatric version) Primary English speaking or fluent in English. No known special education diagnosis excluding a 504 designation. Currently not suffering from a concussion or being treated for a concussion.* No known physical or psychological impairment that would affect their ability to perform the test. Documentation of a known special education diagnosis other than a 504 designation. English is not their primary language nor are they proficient in the English language. Currently suffering from a concussion or being treated for a concussion.* Any known physical or psychological impairment that would affect their ability to perform the test. Note: Unless specifically required by the particular study (i.e., a discriminant validity study differentiating concussed versus nonconcussed individuals).
